titleInfo.title: Systematic Human Rights Violations in Ukraine since Russia's February 2022 Invasion

name.namePart: Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics

mods:mods.abstract: This paper examines human rights violations in Ukraine, attributed to Russia and the self-proclaimed 'republics' of Donetsk and Luhansk. These violations include cases of arbitrary detention, enforced disappearances, torture and ill-treatment, and conflict-related sexual violence (CRSV) against vulnerable populations. Historically, Russia and the self-proclaimed 'republics' have failed to take accountability for their role in committing these offenses, including consistently underreporting data and not allowing human rights monitors to access detainees under their administrations. Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, systematic abuse has been executed against civilians, detainees, and prisoners of war at even greater rates. In this paper, I argue that they are systematic in nature and fit into the framework for atrocity crimes, as defined by the Rome Statute of International Criminal Court. In my literature review, I discuss prior research and reporting by international monitors, who have watched the progression of abuses taking place in Ukraine and their approach to holding those involved, accountable. Within this paper, I use the method of secondary analysis of existing data, by means of triangulation, to converge data pulled from three human rights monitors. These data are extracted from existing data published by nongovernmental organizations that launched monitoring projects in response to the Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, to document numerous, ongoing human rights violations. This thesis discusses how human rights abuses have systematically increased since the invasion, and how human rights monitors have documented them with the use of a secondary analysis of already existing data. I also discuss limitations that arise from their type of reporting and explore how triangulation trivializes missing numbers, by addressing key trends.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Art.
